posts.name: Naroglu
posts.cooked:
Hi y‚Äôall! We are 9th year team, but unlike most of veteran teams, our electronics is still from 2016. I looked up the prices for RoboRio2, PDH etc. and individually they are expensive for us.

Is there a bundle/kit that we can purchase to renew all? Can we buy rookie kit(s) from FIRST itself?

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Two things:

Do they still work?

Can you hold out as-is for 1-2 more seasons?

There‚Äôs a control system refresh due for 2027. If you‚Äôre having trouble affording them all, skip anything you don‚Äôt absolutely have to upgrade and you‚Äôll get a full set then.

With that said, I don‚Äôt know of a single place you can get the entire system as a bundle. What I would suggest for the future is to plan on one or two pieces per season, as a spare/upgrade part, and budget accordingly.
Andymark has a couple bundles for things like the pdp, pdh, and ROBORIO, but most are oos or out of date with the new radios coming into play.

posts.name: Kirby Caldwell
posts.cooked: It also depends how competitive they want to stay as well. The only bundles I know of are from AndyMark, but if you don‚Äôt mind buying second hand I‚Äôm sure a larger regional team has electronics they would sell to you.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: Getting a centralized bundle like this is also unlikely because the control system items come from a variety of different manufacturers, and most of them have a limited number of authorized retailers, in some cases just one. In most cases, the items are rarely if ever offered at a discount while they are stil in production; at least in some cases I suspect this is driven by the manufacturer more than the retailer.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
EricH:

What I would suggest for the future is to plan on one or two pieces per season, as a spare/upgrade part, and budget accordingly.

To piggyback on this: Talk to your local teams, and see if there‚Äôs any higher resource teams that are willing to spot you a spare, or at least earmark something in case of emergency. With the Rio platform on the way out, there‚Äôs little need for teams keep a ton of spares on hand, and even less need to buy new ones to serve as spares. With how often these things break, even a few spares kicking around at a comp can keep everyone up and running.
